lyrics.lyrics: Long ago
Just like the hearse you die to get in again
We are so far from you
Burning on
Just like the match you strike to incinerate
The lives of everyone you know
And what's the worst you take (Worst you take)
From every heart you break (Heart you break)
And like the blade you stain (Blade you stain)
Well, I've been holding on tonight
What's the worst that I can say?
Things are better if I stay
So long and goodnight
So long and goodnight
Came a time
When every star fall
Brought you to tears again
We are the very hurt you sold
And what's the worst you take (Worst you take)
From every heart you break (Heart you break)
And like the blade you stain (Blade you stain)
Well, I've been holding on tonight
What's the worst that I can say?
Things are better if I stay
So long and goodnight
So long and goodnight
Well, if you carry on this way
Things are better if I stay
So long and goodnight
So long and goodnight
Can you hear me?
Are you near me?
Can we pretend to leave and then
We'll meet again
When both our cars collide
What's the worst that I can say?
Things are better if I stay
So long and goodnight
So long and goodnight
Well, if you carry on this way
Things are better if I stay
So long and goodnight
So long and goodnight

annotation:
This is a reference to the title and first line of the Welsh poet, Dylan Thomas‘ 1951 poem “Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night”:

Do not go gentle into that good night,
Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

The reference is a sort of ironic twist on the original line: the speaker seems to wish Helena a loving death.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
And what’s the worst you take (Worst you take)
 From every heart you break? (Heart you break)
annotation: Gerard has said this was an open letter to himself after his grandmother’s death. maybe he’s asking himself if he’s heartbroken enough from her death to take his own life.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
And what’s the worst to take (Worst to take)
 From every heart you break? (Heart you break)
annotation: PROPOSED SUGGESTION: I think it’s talking about the consequences of Gerard’s angry nature. His anger issues got the best of him after his grandmother’s passing, resulting in him breaking the hearts of those around him. Another theory is that maybe this line represents the pain that brings the death of a close relative, friend or lover, it breaks the hearts of many, destroying lives without a care.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
And like the blade you stain (Blade you stain)
 Well, I’ve been holding on tonight
annotation: Along with the previous annotation of this line, this could also refer to the effect a blade has on skin. A blade will stain the skin and leave a scar forever. It can fade and blend in but at the end of the day it will always be there; a daily reminder of the pain they underwent. Her death has permanently lodged itself into the back of his head; something he will never be able to forget. Her death, all in all, has torn and stained the very fabric of their lives, like a blade will stain skin, forever.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
What’s the worst that I can say?
 Things are better if I stay
 So long and goodnight
 So long, and goodnight
 Well, if you carry on this way
 Things are better if I stay
 So long and goodnight
annotation:
Pleading, screaming, or begging till you’re blue in the face isn’t changing anything, so let go. He’s choosing not to go with her because it would just bring more pain. He’s saying goodbye.

Some people are taught to never say goodbye to someone you love because it is considered final. Instead, they use other phrases, like ‘goodnight,’ even if they will never wake up.

This could be referring to Gerard Way’s grandmother, who the song is written for after her passing. She may be gone, but it’s better if he doesn’t follow her.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Came a time when every star fall brought you to tears again
 We are the very hurt you sold
annotation:
This could mean Helena was so fed up with living in pain that every day she lived she’d cry at night wishing on falling stars she’d go in her sleep. Her giving up was her way of selling her life, not thinking about how it would affect her loved ones. He’s calling her selfish in a way.

Also, it can refer to watching a star “fall from grace”, meaning watching someone you love and idolize, like a singer/actor, slowly falling apart and being helpless cause you can’t stop it and in turn crying cause you know how it will end. Artist s live their lives in the public eye, they live through their arts… so they affect us greatly, because as fans we can relate to them in some form or another. They’d sell us their pain, so when they die they take a piece of us with them.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics: What’s the worst that I can say?
annotation: It doesn’t matter what he says or does because he’s angry and hurt, it won’t bring her back.. so in the next line he finally says goodbye.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
And like the blade you stain (Blade you stain)
 Well, I’ve been holding on tonight
annotation:
This line might refer to her having surgery and the blood on the blade that couldn’t help save her now represents him. He’s holding on to pain as thick as blood on a knife blade.

Also, could mean he’s a “cutter”, people who self-mutilate,  replacing one pain by another. He’s fighting the urge to cut deeper and end it… he’s determined to make it though the night.

 Perhaps this could also be a reference to the grim reaper’s scythe if death is being personified.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Burning on, just like a match you strike to incinerate
 The lives of everyone you know
annotation:
The fire represents two things:

  
The death of his grandmother  
The destructive nature of Gerard's actions  



The death affected everyone she knew in a very negative way, almost to say it burnt or “incinerated” them.  Gerard uses the fire metaphor to allude to both his grandmother’s death and his own self-destructive behavior.

Gerard and Mikey’s grandmother, Elena Rush (or Helena), had a huge influence on Gerard’s musical career. She fed his and Mikey’s dreams and supported them in everything they did.

On the surface, Gerard seems angry for her leaving, as if she’s the reason why everyone is hurting.  However, these lyrics act as a letter to himself, expressing the self-hatred he felt at the time.

With this in mind, when he says “you,” he’s referring to himself.  He’s the one who struck the match.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Long ago, just like the Hearse you die to get in again
 We are so far from you
annotation:
Gerard is using the “hearse” in this line to reference the fact that you probably won’t get to ride in one unless you die. Similarly, death is the only way he could be reunited with his grandmother. When he sings “you die to get in again,” he could mean he misses her so much he’d do anything to get her back again, perhaps even commit suicide.



Years after the song’s release, MCR started offering t-shirts with a hearse graphic.

sections.explanation: The first verse begins and introduces the melancholic tone of the song with lyrics reflecting loss.
The first chorus introduces a more powerful and emotional melody, increasing energy significantly.
The second verse returns to a reflective tone but with an increased emotional depth.
The second chorus repeats the powerful motif with slight variations to keep the listener engaged.
The bridge section brings a shift in energy with a more introspective and haunting sound.
The final chorus and outro deliver the climax of the song, bringing all themes together.

song_start.explanation: The song begins with an instrumental introduction and the first lines of the verse, setting a somber and emotional tone.

song_end.explanation: The song ends with the repeated lines of the outro, fading out emotionally.
